Award.AwardTitle: Mathematical Studies of Short-Ranged Spin Glasses
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project addresses a number of basic questions concerning the low temperature behavior of short-range spin glasses and other models of materials with quenched disorder. Rigorous and heuristic mathematical methods will be applied to analyze the conjectured presence of a phase transition; the multiplicity, structure and organization of pure phases and ground states; the effect of small magnetic fields; and non-equilibrium dynamics.





The purpose of this project is to develop mathematical techniques and results in certain specific models of the low temperature properties of disordered materials, known as spin glasses. The importance of the project is that these techniques have potential application, over the long term, to a wide range of problems arising in areas such as theoretical computer science or biology which combine issues of complexity and optimization. Examples of such problems are optimal route scheduling of airlines and predicting the geometric structure (and hence biological function) of proteins.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported the development of mathematical techniques
for studying an important class of magnetic materials
known as spin glasses. Understanding their behavior is essential to filling a gap in
our knowledge of how materials behave when their structure is dominated by randomness
and disorder. The techniques developed also have potential applications to a wide
range of complex problems in other areas, such as computer science and biology. Examples
of such problems are route scheduling of airlines and predicting the geometric structure
(and hence biological function) of proteins.

Despite our detailed knowledge of the solid state of matter, our understanding is generally restricted to solids whose behavior is determined by the fact that the atoms (or other microscopic constituents of the material) are arranged in an ordered array, such that underlying regularities and symmetries can be well-characterized physically and mathematically. When such regularities are absent --- and this occurs in a wide variety of materials, such as glasses, polymers, proteins, and many others --- our understanding is limited, and even the most basic questions remain unanswered.

Among these questions are whether these systems exhibit a phase transition, such as that which occurs when water freezes to ice, and how one characterizes the low-temperature properties of the disordered material. These studies are hampered by a lack of systematic mathematical methods required to approach the difficult problems involved. This was the focus of  research conducted during the grant period.

Although these problems remain open, the PI and co-PI made significant progress in developing new approaches to both the phase transition problem and to that of characterizing the low-temperature structure of disordered materials.  Work done under this grant on the first of these in particular makes close contact with the theory of random graphs, a field that brings together mathematicians and computer scientists working in the area of combinatorial probability.

Work done under this grant on the relation of spin glasses to complexity science is of potential interest to computer scientists working on hard combinatorial optimization problems, biologists working on neural nets, evolutions, and protein folding and dynamics, and possibly some aspects of social science.

Along the way, the PI and co-PI trained two graduate students, one postdoctoral researcher, and two undergraduates. They gave lectures at "summer schools" consisting of an international assortment of graduate students in various fields, and wrote a "primer" on the subject for scientists and students in the areas of physics, mathematics, chemistry, biology, computer science, engineering, and the social sciences. A copy of the cover of that forthcoming book is attached.
